lab_cheat.advanced_functions module¶

lab_cheat.advanced_functions.curve_fit(f: Callable, x: GroupVar, y: GroupVar, p0: Optional[Sequence[SupportsFloat]] = None)[source]¶

Makes curve function approximation. Unfortunately, ignores x.err()

Parameters:

  • f – the function we want to approximate

  • x – an array on x-axis

  • y – an array on y-axis

  • p0 – parameter to curve_fit

Returns:

coefficients of approximated curve

lab_cheat.advanced_functions.fmax(f: Callable, x0: Union[Var, SupportsFloat], x: Optional[GroupVar] = None, y: Optional[GroupVar] = None) → Union[Var, SupportsFloat][source]¶

fmax is for very accurate search of maximum of known graph

Parameters:

  • f – function to maximize

  • x0 – dot near maximum

  • x – to find the error accurately

  • y – to find the error accurately

Returns:

x_max

Parameters:

lab_cheat.advanced_functions.sigma(variable: Union[GroupVar, Sequence])[source]¶

Calculates standard deviation of values in variable

Parameters:

variable – a variable

Returns:

sqrt from the variance

lab_cheat.advanced_functions.slicer(var: GroupVar, left_val: Optional[SupportsFloat] = None, right_val: Optional[SupportsFloat] = None, excluding: Optional[List[SupportsFloat]] = None) → List[int][source]¶

Makes list of indexes of variables which value is between given borders except the nearest vars to numbers in exluding list

Parameters:

  • var – GroupVar that contains variables

  • left_val – left border. If None then -infinity.

  • right_val – right border. If None then +infinity.

  • excluding – If None then []

Ex: >>> v = GroupVar(range(10), 0) >>> s = slicer(v, left_val=1.1, right_val=8, excluding=[3.1, 6.3, 0]) >>> v[s].val() [2.0, 4.0, 5.0, 7.0, 8.0]

lab_cheat.advanced_functions.smoothing(x: Union[List, GroupVar], y: Union[List, GroupVar], smooth_factor) → Callable[source]¶

Smoothing of the function

Parameters:

  • x – an array on x-axis

  • y – an array on y-axis

  • smooth_factor – smooth_factor in _UnivariateSpline

Returns:

smoothing function

lab_cheat.advanced_functions.sorting(x: Union[List, GroupVar], y: Union[List, GroupVar]) → Tuple[Union[List, GroupVar], Union[List, GroupVar]][source]¶

!!! x and y must be the same type !!! Sorts pairs of data to make xt raising

Returns:

the same types as x and y.

lab_cheat.plot.mnk(x: Union[GroupVar, Sequence], y: Union[GroupVar, Sequence], figure: Optional[Figure] = None, colour: Optional[str] = None, line_style: Optional[str] = None, label: Optional[str] = None) → Tuple[Var, Var][source]¶

This method counts two types of errors: those caused by errors and those caused by statistics. If the points lie well on the line, then the error due to errors will prevail. If the points are measured extremely accurately, but they lie badly on a straight line, then the statistical error prevails. The resulting error is the root sum of the squares of the two types of these errors.

Parameters:

  • x – the sequence of points on x-axis

  • y – the sequence of points on y-axis

  • figure – the spot where the fpath will display

  • colour – colour of the line

  • line_style – style of the line

  • label – the inscription that will reflect in the legend

Returns:

coefficients of the straight

lab_cheat.plot.mnk_through0(x: GroupVar, y: GroupVar, figure: Optional[Figure] = None, colour: Optional[str] = None, line_style: Optional[str] = None, label: Optional[str] = None) → Var[source]¶

This method builds mnk through the point (0, 0)

Parameters:

  • x – the sequence of points on x-axis

  • y – the sequence of points on y-axis

  • figure – the spot where the fpath will display

  • colour – colour of the line

  • line_style – style of the line

  • label – the inscription that will reflect in the legend

Returns:

coefficient of the straight

  • colours – colours that are displayed in the table

  • floatrow – to accommodate some tables in the row

  • color_frequency – frequency of the colours

the table in tkinter-window

lab_cheat.var module¶

class lab_cheat.var.GroupVar(variables: Sequence[Var], exp=0)[source]¶
class lab_cheat.var.GroupVar(values: Sequence[SupportsFloat], errors: Sequence[SupportsFloat], exp=0)
class lab_cheat.var.GroupVar(values: Sequence[SupportsFloat], error: SupportsFloat, exp=0)

Bases: object

This class implements the idea of a series of similar measurements. The behavior is the same as in numpy arrays. So, adding, multiplying of two GroupVar is corresponding operation between Vars inside GroupVars. The only slot in this class is ‘variables’. It’s a list containing Vars. (To read documentation to this class, it’s necessary to understand the same methods in Var class.)

err() → List[float][source]¶
Returns:

list of errors

val() → List[float][source]¶
Returns:

list of values

val_err() → Tuple[Tuple[float, ...], Tuple[float, ...]][source]¶
Returns:

Tuple consisting of (tuple of values) and (tuple of errors)

class lab_cheat.var.Var(_story: Expr, exp: int = 0)[source]¶
class lab_cheat.var.Var(value: SupportsFloat, error: SupportsFloat, exp: int = 0)

Bases: object

Class Var is one of the main classes in lab_cheat. It is used to store the pair of value and error of any directly measured variable OR the function of how to calculate indirect variable from direct variables. There is no public slots in this class. For series of similar variables it’s more convenient to use GroupVar.

err() → float[source]¶
Returns:

error of your variable

The following is to explain how does library finds it:

In most cases we have random independent errors of variables:

delta(f(x1, x2, …)) ~= sqrt( (df/dx1 * delta(x1))**2 + (df/dx2 * delta(x2))**2 + … ),

where the error by x1 for example in this method is calculated by:

df/dx1 * delta(x1) = (f(x1+dx1, x2, …) - f(x1 - dx1, x2, …)) * BIG_NUMBER / 2 dx1 = delta(x1) / BIG_NUMBER

As you see, it’s very similar to finding partial derivative numerically. You may change BIG_NUMBER in function ‘set_big_number’ in this module. (default is 50)

val() → float[source]¶
Returns:

value of your variable

val_err() → Tuple[float, float][source]¶
Returns:

tuple containing value and error

(This method is more efficient than calling val() and err() separately.)

lab_cheat.var.digital_accuracy(val: float, err: float) → int[source]¶

Finds needed number of digits. If the first significant (different from zero) digit is 1 or 2, the method rounds values and errors up to the next digit. Else the method rounds values and errors up to the first significant digit.

Returns:

amount of digits after the decimal point

lab_cheat.var.digital_normalize_str(str_val, str_err, accuracy) → str[source]¶

This method uses digital_accuracy

Parameters:

  • str_val – a value in string format

  • str_err – an error in string format

  • accuracy – None

Returns:

string looking like “value pm error”, where value end error are rounded.

lab_cheat.var.digital_normalize_tuple(str_val, str_err, accuracy) → tuple[source]¶

The same as digital_normalize_str but returns tuple of value and error

Parameters:

  • str_val – a value in string format

  • str_err – an error in string format

  • accuracy – accuracy

Returns:

tuple containing from value and error of the variable

lab_cheat.var.estimated_error(func: Callable[[...], float], values: array, err_vector: array, val: float)[source]¶

This method calculates error of an indirect measurement. We catch warnings turning them to errors. If errors is too big, method returns RunTimeWarning exception.

Parameters:

  • func – some function that is applied to values

  • values – values of variables that enter the function

  • err_vector – errors of a direct measurement

  • val – a value

lab_cheat.var.set_big_number(n: int)[source]¶

look in Var.err documentation

lab_cheat.var.set_error_accuracy(accuracy: float)[source]¶

Look in Var.__str__ documentation

lab_cheat.var.set_value_accuracy(accuracy: float)[source]¶

Look in Var.__str__ documentation

lab_cheat.var.suitable_accuracy(val: float, err: float) → int[source]¶

Finds needed number of digits. Digits that have the same order as the 30% error will not be shown. If error is zero, there won’t be shown digits having the same order as 5% value. (30% and 5% may be changed in ‘set_error_accuracy’ and ‘value_accuracy’ respectively.)

Returns:

amount of digits after the decimal point

lab_cheat.var.suitable_normalize(var: Var, accuracy: Optional[int] = None) → str[source]¶

This method uses suitable_accuracy

Parameters:

  • var – a variable

  • accuracy – number of shown digits

Returns:

string looking like “value pm error”, where value end error are rounded.
